extractions.extraction_text: structured data is a collection of data organized in certain formats, often in rows and columns, with a clear, predictable structure.

attributes.definition: A collection of data organized in certain formats, often in rows and columns, with a clear, predictable structure.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Data that is neatly organized, like in a spreadsheet with rows and columns, where each piece of information has a clear place and meaning.

extractions.extraction_text: Unstructured data is they will change. Sometimes you don't really know how to interpret them. Currently that the human generate content such as image, text, video, we consider them as unstructured data.

attributes.definition: Data that changes and is sometimes difficult to interpret, such as human-generated content like images, text, and videos.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Data that doesn't have a predefined organization, like photos, written documents, or videos, making it harder to analyze directly.

extractions.extraction_text: Currently that the human generate content such as image, text, video, we consider them as unstructured data.

attributes.summary_of_insight: Images, text, and videos are examples of unstructured data.

extractions.extraction_text: Luckily with this AI thing and right now text, image, video already can be converting into structured format, but you still need to be able to know once we convert, are they meaningful or not.

attributes.summary_of_insight: AI can help convert unstructured data into a structured format, but human interpretation is still needed to ensure the data is meaningful.

attributes.definition: The number of features or attributes in a data set.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Refers to the number of different characteristics or variables being measured in a dataset.

attributes.definition: The phenomenon where data becomes increasingly sparse and algorithms perform poorly as the number of dimensions increases.
attributes.simplified_explanation: When a dataset has too many features, it becomes very spread out and difficult for algorithms to find meaningful patterns.

extractions.extraction_text: Sparsity comes from a key word called sparse. Sparse means very few.

attributes.definition: The state of data where most values are zero or absent, meaning very few data points are present in relation to the total possible.
attributes.simplified_explanation: When a dataset has many possible entries but only a few actual data points are filled in, making it 'sparse'.

extractions.extraction_text: If you have the record in e-commerce store, like in Amazon. Your data is sparse in that data record. Because they have millions of the record, but then you probably only buy 10 books before. So make your data in the millions then become very sparse.

attributes.summary_of_insight: An e-commerce example illustrating sparsity: millions of records exist, but a single user might only have a few transactions, making their data sparse.

attributes.definition: The level of detail or granularity of the data.
attributes.simplified_explanation: How finely detailed the data is; for example, daily sales versus yearly sales.

attributes.summary_of_insight: The scale at which data is viewed (its resolution) affects the patterns that can be observed.

extractions.extraction_text: data matrix. If each object has the same fixed set of numeric attributes.

attributes.definition: If each object has the same fixed set of numeric attributes.
attributes.simplified_explanation: A table where each row represents an item and each column represents a numerical characteristic of that item.

extractions.extraction_text: Okay, they can become data metric. And then we allow them to do the ratio operation. All the value inside need to become the ratio data. So then right here, they need to be ratio data.

attributes.summary_of_insight: For data matrices, all values must be ratio data to allow for mathematical operations.

extractions.extraction_text: document data is a part that we were talking about later because before 2013, this is before 2013. Okay. And the people actually utilize document data in a vector form. Right here. So they select important keyword in the document. And then after that, for every document, you utilize those important keyword, we got some number, occurrence of the number for that keyword right there. We generate a something called term vector. So each one of them are vector.

attributes.definition: Utilized in a vector form by selecting important keywords in the document and counting their occurrences to generate a term vector.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Representing documents as numerical vectors based on keyword frequencies, a method used before 2013.

extractions.extraction_text: Why vector? Because in computer science, vector is the way for us to operate. We convert them to vector, so in other word, every number right here are become ratio data.

attributes.summary_of_insight: Documents are converted to vectors because vectors are the standard format for computational operations in computer science, requiring ratio data.

extractions.extraction_text: But that is way we try to work in that before 2013. After 2013, how we try to do that? We will talking about that in the text mining part. So maybe three weeks later.

attributes.summary_of_insight: The method described for document data is outdated (pre-2013); newer methods will be discussed later in the text mining section.

text:
# LECTURE ANALYSIS: Types of Data Sets
## Video Segment: 110:58 - 114:58

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Data Sets". It lists two main categories: Structured Data Sets and Unstructured Data Sets. Structured data is described as a collection of data organized in certain formats, often in rows and columns, with a clear, predictable structure. Unstructured data is described as more complex and varied, usually derived from human-generated content like text, images, and videos.

[TRANSCRIPT - 110:58]
So the next one we want to talking about the data set. We have different type of data set. You might heard about the term called structured data or unstructured data. Structured data is you know exactly the meaning about the row and column. Unstructured data is they will change. Sometimes you don't really know how to interpret them. Currently that the human generate content such as image, text, video, we consider them as unstructured data.

[TRANSCRIPT - 111:36]
Luckily with this AI thing and right now text, image, video already can be converting into structured format, but you still need to be able to know once we convert, are they meaningful or not.

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Characteristics of Data Sets". It lists three characteristics: Dimensionality (Curse of Dimensionality), Sparsity (Only presence counts), and Resolution (Patterns depend on the scale). A speech bubble says "Later" next to Sparsity.

[TRANSCRIPT - 111:53]
So we have different kind of characteristic about our data dimension we mentioned before. Sparsity comes from a key word called sparse. Sparse means very few. Like what we say that if you have the record in e-commerce store, like in Amazon. Your data is sparse in that data record. Because they have millions of the record, but then you probably only buy 10 books before. So make your data in the millions then become very sparse. So data are sparse. And sometimes in certain place, we will also talking about the resolution. And that part about sparsity, how to solving them, how to do the resolution, we will talking about later in some of the courses, some of them will be in classification, some of them will be in the text mining.

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Types of Data Sets". It lists three types: Data Matrix, Document Data, and Transaction Data.

[TRANSCRIPT - 112:58]
We want to talk about different type of the data set. We have the data matrix, document data, transaction data. So data matrix look like this way. If each object has the same fixed set of numeric attributes. Okay, they can become data metric. And then we allow them to do the ratio operation. All the value inside need to become the ratio data. So then right here, they need to be ratio data.

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Data Matrix". It states: "If each object has the same fixed set of numeric attributes". A table shows "Book 1" to "Book 5" with columns for "Price", "Sells", "# Reviews", and "# Readers". The values are numeric.

[TRANSCRIPT - 114:48]
Okay. And the document data is a part that we were talking about later because before 2013, this is before 2013. Okay. And the people actually utilize document data in a vector form. Right here. So they select important keyword in the document. And then after that, for every document, you utilize those important keyword, we got some number, occurrence of the number for that keyword right there. We generate a something called term vector. So each one of them are vector. Why vector? Because in computer science, vector is the way for us to operate. We convert them to vector, so in other word, every number right here are become ratio data. But that is way we try to work in that before 2013. After 2013, how we try to do that? We will talking about that in the text mining part. So maybe three weeks later.
